Sunburst rounds the percentages and values up to 1 significant figure (.1s), which is a rare wish for such a figure. Output formatting would be nice to have on the style tab, but reasonable defaults shouldn't hurt either. Please revert to something more useful, such as .3s .

@ahsanshah I hear you. I am facing a similar issue.

AIUI the current permission systems are about access to dashboards, charts and data-sources. That's a level above what we want (i.e we want to have granular permissions based access to the data *within* those charts).

Here is an initial thought on how maybe superset could be patched to make this work:

1) When creating users, have a set of arbitrary key/values that you can populate for that user. It could be things like 'user_id', 'department' etc. The point here is to add key/values that we would want to later filter on.
2) When creating Charts, where the 'Add Filter' is, have an 'Add User Filter' option. This might look the same as the regular Filter option, except the value would be a key that we had previously entered as the user. It might look something like storing a bindparam for later interpolation.
3) `Table.get_sqla_query()` would then build our query just like it does now, although in addition to a `filter` key, it could also look for `user_filter` (or whatever), and would do a `getattr(flask.g.user, user_filter.val)` or similar to get the user specific value that we are filtering against.

You'd obviously have to consider what to do if the User doesn't have the attribute, as well as other possible complexities I haven't thought of. 

If those who know Superset better than I think this is a reasonable approach I'd be happy to get on and write a patch, because as much as I'd like to use Superset, without this kind of feature it's of limited use to me :( 

@mistercrunch As to the security around the WHERE clause, is it possible for the user to pass in arbitrary filters to a GET call? If it isn't possible, and if they cannot modify the Chart then the WHERE clause should be secure...right ?
(People coming here via Google might be interested in [this stackoverflow question](https://stackoverflow.com/q/51872791/562769))

My bad. I realized that internally we do an additional permissions check that runs through [that](https://github.com/apache/incubator-superset/blob/master/superset/connectors/sqla/models.py#L892) `default_query` when editing tables. However, I can see some issues with applying that filter to the underlying `default_query` when the intention was just to remove clutter from the table list. Is there a particular reason why the filter exists there as well as in the URL params?
@williaster, are you ok with moving forward and merging this PR, and then changing the way the tag component is display in dashboards?
Perhaps change `"0.0.172"` to `"^0.0.172"` so it will pick up newer version without breaking changes as well.

`0.0.172` and `^0.0.172` actually should be equivalent here, either way.

Below a `1.0.0`, everything is considered a breaking change so if you specify `^0.0.172` and `^0.0.185` is released, it will still be `^0.0.172`.

@nik-crisp - here is what I would do for debugging. 1) Check if your superset email configuration is working. ```python # superset shell >>> from superset.utils import send_email_smtp >>> from superset import app >>> send_email_smtp('recipient@gmail.com', 'Hello', 'Test content', app.config) ``` This should verify that your email configuration is working. Once that is verified, please try it on celery as follows 1) start celery with `-l DEBUG` to see debug logs 2) Ensure that you are start celery with the beat option `-B` option or starting a separate Beat worker with `-l DEBUG`. Check that 1) beat job is getting scheduled 2) The time stamp for when the job is getting scheduled 3) error messages when the job runs or tries to send an email Are you running on OSX. What is the timezone on your box? I am seeing a weird issue with celery and UTC timezones on OSX. Working on a fix.

Hey there @sylvia-tomiyama,

Thanks for taking a look at this and giving the user's experience some thought. I agree that some of the terminology surrounding the feature needs to be defined more clearly since there's some ambiguity around the term "published". You hit the nail on the head when you said that **My understanding is that unpublished dashboards are viewable, but less discoverable** – which is further bolstered by your distinction of _prod vs in-progress_. I think the comment about migration (which mentioned that dashboards would all of the sudden be gone) was referring to the visibility of them within these list views but they would not actually be gone or become truly unviewable. With that in mind I've considered some of the excellent points you've made and here's what I think:

### Welcome List & CRUD View List for Dashboards
You mentioned as a part of your understanding that the visibility of the dashboard will change on the `/welcome` page but not the crud view. This wasn't quite my intention since when I was developing the feature these both used the same `/dashboardmodelview/list` endpoint and displayed the same dashboards. However I think it's a good idea to show admins all of the dashboards on the crud list view and to include a column of whether or not it's published for filtering. The alternative would make it so that even admins wouldn't be able to see these dashboards unless they performed a query which is less than ideal. 

Right now I say that only admins should be able to see all dashboards because I believe this view is used more frequently for finding dashboards than `/welcome` (considering I'm not aware of a way to return to `/welcome` except by setting the URL specifically). If the Superset icon in the top left returned the user to this view instead of the profile I would say it should affect just the welcome page and not the CRUD view but since most people use the CRUD view to find dashboards once they're in the application I think the feature should de-clutter that view as well. Perhaps the _profile_ button under the human icon in the top-right can become the `/profile` page and then an edit button on that page can take you to `/users/userinfo`? It seems like this may be more intuitive even without this feature we're discussing haha.

###   Displaying and Altering the Published Status
I think you make a great point about the eye icon being a bit misleading and a bit too subtle. I think a better solution might be something like a [_draft_] badge next to the title of the dashboard (possibly with a hover-over tooltip) which indicates a few things:

- The dashboard they're viewing will not show up in the list of dashboards, they should favorite it to see it in that list along with the others
- The elements used in the dashboard are tentative and subject to change
- Users should consider whether or not it is okay for them to share the dashboard before doing so

This indicator seems like it would make the intention of the feature much more understandable.
 
As for altering the status, I think you're totally right that it makes more sense to put this in the actions dropdown especially if we forgo the icon which was both the indicator and the toggle.

### The Way Forward
Here's a couple of action items which I think are appropriate after this discussion for me to work on:

- [x] Replace the eye icon with a [draft] badge of sorts next to the title of unpublished dashboards.
- [x] Add ability to toggle published status in the action dropdown menu 
- [x] Add published field to CRUD listing of dashboards for sorting / filtering

Let me know what you think and thanks again for your consideration :)

@betodealmeida @mistercrunch

@mmuru I think I figured out your problems

1) `Could not build url for endpoint u'Superset.dashboard'` - this is because in the schedule screen, you may not have configured a dashboard. Looks like the dashboard is set to `None`. Does your schedules dashboard have a `None` entry in it?
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/115988/44239676-5b4cc600-a16f-11e8-9a24-713691539fd6.png)

I have pushed out a change to prevent this situation. Can you please change/update/edit and try again?

2) If you are having issues with ChromeDriver, can you try defaulting to Firefox and try?

3) I will take that as a feature request. Can you please create one on Github and assign it to me? I will work on it after this PR is merged (if it is merged :-) )

4) The crontab UI is working as expected. Let me try to explain how this is supposed to work.
* As per `CELERYBEAT_SCHEDULE`, every hour at the 1st minute, we fire off the `email_reports.schedule_hourly` task. This is meant to run _exactly once_ every hour.
* `email_reports.schedule_hourly` goes through all the scheduled entries and figures out if any job needs to be executed in that particular hour.
* If there are tasks that need running, `email_reports.schedule_hourly` will schedule them with celery (using the `eta` argument).

I hope this clears up your questions.

I also have other features which are waiting to be done on top of this branch. Wrangling this is become a big pain. I would greatly appreciate a merge or a reject, so I can decide on the path forward. Is there a group/mailing list where I can ask for help?

Hmm, @kristw and @conglei and I discussed this because some users were upset about changing their old charts.

I think we aligned on starting at 0 as still being the best default, so I think we don't want to push this. We thought a better solution for keeping current users happy would be migrating existing slices to have the default, so that they don't change, but then all future charts will require consciously changing it to not start at 0. krist/conglei any other thoughts?

@mmuru pushed a fix. thank you.

@mmuru that is a very good question. A few years ago, I had designed a similar system for doing reports. Let me explain why it would fail here.

1. Handling change of schedules is very complex. Celery beat works by mostly having a static set of crontab schedules for it's jobs. It is not well designed to handle dynamically changing schedules. If a user changes the schedule for an email delivery, we have to update beat to cancel an old schedule and then install a new schedule. I don't know if beat supports something like this. Even if it does, we will have to keep track of a beat's internal db reference with a dashboar's/slice's schedule (in another table).  My approach is simpler (IMHO). You use celerybeat to run a job once an hour (a static config) and everything else is dynamic. The user can install/update/delete email reports and we don't care. We use the latest crontab entries for each job as-is.

2. No hard dependency on beat. In the future, we can use frameworks like luigi or a simple Unix crontab script to invoke the hourly job. (and get rid of beat)

3. At [Affirm](https://tech.affirm.com/), we are heavy users of celery and run millions of celery tasks every day, but we have experienced a lot of difficulty in running and managing beat jobs - specially the ones which need dynamic schedules. We run just one beat job on production now which will be deprecated soon.

@mahendra: Thanks for the fix and the detailed explanation on the celery beat scheduling implementation. We can use Apache Airflow, Luigi or simple UNIX cron for scheduling and delivering reports when you expose the rest APIs to generate slices and dashboards.
@mahendra: I found another issue with celery beat scheduling. It does not pick up the latest or updated crontab entry instead it uses the previous crontab entry.

@mahendra: The current behavior is the scheduled tasks are executed 1st minute of the hour irrespective of the crontab task value. For example, the task is scheduled for '10 11 * * *' and if the celery beat is still running then this task is executed 11am-12pm interval at 11.01am but not at 11.10am. Also, if the celery beat is not running then this task will never get executed even celery beat is restarted after 11am.  The tasks are need to be executed what we specified in the crontab and also tasks not being run and should be executed in case of celery beat is restarted.

Hello, full-disclosure, I'm not a user of superset (although, it looks awesome!), I'm just browsing and had a question:

Why go with React components instead of an iframe based approach? Seems like the latter affords more flexibility from implementation, maintenance and usage perspectives?
@mmuru i am investigating the issue. I believe this is due to timezone settings. Will get back to you on it. (worked fine on a machine in UTC mode).

@tiffon good question. 

we already support embedding charts (and dahsboards) with an iframe via a `url?standalone=true` flag. we've customized the queries of these charts with some success, but it doesn't allow for a pattern where you might want to expose vis controls easily. you could do this within the Superset code with url parameters but that adds more complexity. 

instead we'd like to introduce modular data providers (for data sources and queries) and embeddable charts to enable greater flexibility in apps which hope to leverage the Superset backend. you could imagine wanting to build a complex visualization in another web app, but wanting to leverage Superset data to power it. This would also support that use case.

finally, we also expect that the modularity that's enforced by this approach will also greatly reduce coupled code/related bugs.

Also, here is a way you can implement your own Dashboard level filtering without touching the Superset codebase. Roughly speaking you need to do the following:

1. Create a custom view and override the `/superset/explore_json` endpoint
2. Modify the Viz `query_obj()` method to include any additional filtering you want.
3. Import the custom view via the FLASK_APP_MUTATOR.

It looks something like this.

```
from flask import g
from flask_appbuilder import expose
from superset import appbuilder
from superset.views.core import Superset, log_this, has_access_api

class MyCustomView(Superset):

    @log_this
    @has_access_api
    @expose('/explore_json/<datasource_type>/<datasource_id>/', methods=['GET', 'POST'])
    @expose('/explore_json/', methods=['GET', 'POST'])
    def explore_json(self, *args, **kwargs):
        """ This is a copy of the method definition from Superset """
        return super(MyCustomView, self).explore_json(*args, **kwargs)

    def get_viz(self, *args, **kwargs):
        """ Return the Vizualisation object

        get_viz() overrides the Superset.get_viz() method
        so it can wrap it and alter the filter pattern
        that it produces. This is so we can filter
        viz objects by whatever we want.
        """
        viz_obj = super(DAView, self).get_viz(*args, **kwargs)
        # The viz_obj has a query_obj() method which will be called
        # and filters added before being fetched from the DB.
        # We want to wrap this function, so when called we add our own
        # filtering
        def wrapped(f):
            def inner(*args, **kwargs):
                query_obj = f(*args, **kwargs)
                # If we want here we can check the dashboard first 
                dashboard = urllib.urlparse(request.headers['referer']).path
                if dashboard == '/superset/dashboard/dashboardX'/:
                    # Then filter by username
                    query_obj['filter'].append({'val': f'{g.user.username}', 'op': '==', 'col': 'username'})
                return query_obj
            return inner
        viz_obj.query_obj = wrapped(viz_obj.query_obj)
        return viz_obj

# Here we are making sure that any calls to explore_json()
# will call our custom view, thus giving us control of the response
for rule in appbuilder.app.url_map.iter_rules():
    if rule.rule == '/superset/explore_json/':
        rule.endpoint = 'MyCustomView.explore_json'

appbuilder.app.url_map.update()
appbuilder.add_view_no_menu(DAView)
```

Then in your superset `config.py` file add the following:
```

def import_stuff(app):
    from my_app import views
FLASK_APP_MUTATOR = import_stuff
```

Here the `views` module has our previosuly defined `MyCustomView` class etc.

I tried this on 0.26 and it seemed to work fine. This will get called for every chart AFAICT, so you might have to be clever about what filters you are applying for what charts etc. The above is just a basic example.

If this is a pivot table, then in the visualizer, you need to go under Pivot Options, click on number format, type d (for digit), then click Create option "d". The default number format uses a fixed number of significant digits, which is not well explained in the documentation. If you want to format the number differently, they link to this: [https://github.com/d3/d3-format](https://github.com/d3/d3-format)

Good idea with the data shape. I can start from defining `propTypes` for each chart.

@victornoel also good questions! 

I think it's actually easier to answer your second question first. It's a bit beyond the scope of this SIP (another one will be posted shortly that describes this in depth) but we are hoping to refactor the frontend code into a series of NPM packages, for the time being you could imagine `@superset/connection` (for data-related components) and `@superset/charts`(for chart related components) packages. You could then import individual Superset visualizations or a component we're thinking of as a `"<SuperChart id={123} />"` component that could take a chart id and render any vis type.

As for exposing controls like group bys and filters in another application, here's an overview of some different usage scenarios we have thought about with associated components. If the app using the embeddable charts knows about column metadata, it can create the appropriate group bys and filters that then affect the query for the chart. (note this doesn't use the filter widget specifically, the other application would need to write the logic for controls; in the long-run we would also hope to create `@superset/controls` package to expose these types of controls out of the box)
